title: Almost only "did-not-attest"
body: ## Description On [BeaconScan (my validator address)](https://beaconscan.com/validator/0xa5fe01a1d0912e7784c03b4c79bf8cb82a8f1e878a8bc67f40f4307c0934e6610939ee320356bab7af6b48588eca213c#attestations), I can see that I'm losing funds, and on "attestation" I see almost only "did-not-attest. I'm running on a maxed out Mac Mini M1 (16GB RAM) with a 1000 mbit/s down and up broadband connection. ## Version ```sh $ lighthouse --version Lighthouse v1.3.0-3a24ca5 BLS Library: blst Specs: mainnet (true), minimal (false), v0.12.3 (false) ``` ```sh $ rustc --version rustc 1.52.1 (9bc8c42bb 2021-05-09) ``` Running **_stable_**, on commit `3a24ca5f14c6e6d6612fd43eca82aa0c1e6aba16` ## Present Behaviour From the logs of my to active shells, one running `bn --staking` and the other one running `vc` the logs are green and everything looks good? I have not fully synced Eth 1.0 with `geth` locally yet. Asked for [help on Reddit here](https://www.reddit.com/r/ethstaker/comments/nfiuhj/made_mistake_sent_32_eth_before_gethfinished/) and got a tip about being able to use Infura until geth has synced. So created an Infura account and an Eth1 project and one Eth2 project with infura. I'm running `geth` syncing Eth1.0 while running the two lighthouse commands with these settings: ### `bn --staking` ```sh lighthouse --network mainnet bn --staking --eth1-endpoints https://mainnet.infura.io/v3/<32_HEX_PROJECT_ID> ``` (ðŸ¤” Is it weird that I **only** provided the _project id_ and not an API _secret_?) I did not start any NTP service on my Mac Mini, I did not find any for macOS? Is that bad? ### `vc` Started with command: ```sh lighthouse --network mainnet vc --beacon-nodes https://:@eth2-beacon-mainnet.infura.io ``` Log is... all green and almost only filled with `Connected mine, but I don't see any info in logs about failed to attest, so I would expected a warning message, more than the one about possible unsynced local time, about failed attestation. But according to [BeaconScan (my validator address)](https://beaconscan.com/validator/0xa5fe01a1d0912e7784c03b4c79bf8cb82a8f1e878a8bc67f40f4307c0934e6610939ee320356bab7af6b48588eca213c#attestations), I fail to attest. ## Steps to resolve N/A ## Note I'm a developer myself, I appreciate that submitting issues like this without reporting any bug in your code is not really the intent. I do apologize, I kindly ask for any help, am I simply using the wrong params?

Right now your VC is only using the Infura BN. I recommend adding your local beacon node in there ahead of the Infura node:

```
lighthouse vc --beacon-nodes http://localhost:5052,https://infura_url
```

If that configuration still has issues we can look into clock sync & things related to running on M1.

@michaelsproul Thanks, I will try, can you please shed some light on what that means? Do I need to open port 5022? I've only opened 30300 for Geth and 9000 for Lighthouse? Or is this really just locally, so that the two (other lighthouse process being `bn --staking`) can "interact"?
OK cool now I see `Connected to beacon node(s) synced: 2, available: 2, total: 2, service: notifier`, so now connected to **myself** (localhost)  and Infura.
Yeah, no need to open the port, it's just for a local connection between VC and BN

@michaelsproul Thank you VERY much, that (including `http://localhost:5052` as beacon-node) seemed to have fixed it!

Now I'm curios why it is default behaviour to let it be excluded when specifying another one in the list? To me, it seems non-intuitive that my locally running one was so easily ignored. Can we maybe have a discussion about chaning this behaviour? I see many different solutions:
1. Always include `http://localhost:5052` (or at least try to connect to at a regular basis, warn/inform if not running)
2. Prompt user in CLI "Are you SURE you want to ignore the locally running beacon node?" Y/n?" (potentially after having pinged `http://localhost:5052` to see it is indeed running, under the assumption `bn --staking` service was started before `vc`) 
3. Schedule to at a regular interval check if `http://localhost:5052` is running and if not included, inform/warn user

Hmm I relealize that some of these might be overlapping... Anyway, you see where I'm getting at :)

> Thank you VERY much, that (including http://localhost:5052 as beacon-node) seemed to have fixed it!

No worries, I'm glad to hear it :blush:

> Can we maybe have a discussion about changing this behaviour?

That's a good suggestion, thanks! I'll discuss it with the team. In general we try to keep the validator client's codebase as simple as possible because it's security critical. I think that your suggestion (3) might be acceptable on the user-friendliness/security tradeoff, but I need to think about it. If you haven't seen the Lighthouse Book you might be interested in checking it out, in particular the section on configuring redundancy shows setting up the local BN alongside an external one: https://lighthouse-book.sigmaprime.io/redundancy.html

I'll close this issue, but please reach out if you have any other questions :relaxed:
